summary: A rare neuroendocrine neoplasm that can develop at various body sites. When found in the adrenal gland, they are called pheochromocytomas. They are rare tumors with an incidence of about 1 in 300,000. Long-term follow-up is recommended for all individuals with paraganglioma as there is no test to distinguish benign from malignant tumors.
causes: Mutations of the genes for succinate dehydrogenase (SDHD, SDHA, SDHC, SDHB)
Mutations of SDHB gene (familial adrenal pheochromocytoma and extra-adrenal paraganglioma)
Mutations of SDHAF2, VHL, NF1, TMEM127, MAX and SLC25A11 genes
Chromaffin-negative glomus cells derived from embryonic neural crest
symptoms: Ipsilateral weakness of upper trapezius and sternocleiodomastoid muscles
